intro: Moquilea hypoleuca, commonly known as the white moquilea, is a flowering plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and is adapted to the arid climate of the islands. Its leaves are palmate, with five to seven lobes, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds. Moquilea hypoleuca plays a role in the local ecosystem by providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for small invertebrates.
